IPHS SECTION
Retrospect and prospect: a review of research contributions on China's planning history (2011-2020)
Mengfei Tong
, Baihao Li
and Zhao Li
School of Architecture, Southeast University, Nanjing, People's Republic of China;
School of Architecture and Urban Planning, Shandong Jianzhu University, Jinan, People's Republic of China
ABSTRACT

This article focuses on the results of published research into China's urban planning history since 2011. A total of 1,057 articles were selected, including 198 theses, 465 journal papers, and 394 conference papers. It provides quantitative statistics and analysis of the literature, using CiteSpace to conduct a bibliometric analysis of the data. Based on quantitative analysis and supported by the literature, this paper qualitatively concludes and summarizes the research hotspots and evolution of Chinese urban planning history from five dimensions: planning practice, system construction, thought and theory, figures, and discipline. The achievements delve into the exploration of motivations and mechanisms, planning ideology, methodology, practice subjects, and preparation process based on a staged review of the historical process of practice and a summary of its characteristics, which shows a process from partial to holistic and fragmented to systematic in general terms, contributing to the formation of a complete planning history research system. A comprehensive analysis of quantitative statistics, knowledge mapping of literature, and important research content reveals the characteristics of research into the history of Chinese urban planning over the past decade.
KEYWORDS
Introduction

The origin and development of urban planning history studies in China have gone through a unique process. Planning history research in China stemmed from urban construction history as a branch of architectural history in the 1950s. Most early studies are scattered amongst architectural history publications. Planning history subsequently emerged as a separate field, with the gradual independence and expansion of urban planning and as a result of the accumulation of research into the history of urban construction undertaken since 1959. During the 1990s, research into Chinese urban planning was enriched by various historical studies of larger cities with a colonial past, such as Shanghai, Wuhan, and Tianjin. At the same time, scholars began to pay attention to and participate in international activities, such as joined the IPHS, contributed to international conferences. Rich experience has been gained in this process, such as research frontier and new methods, which further promoted the study of planning history. Since the beginning of the twenty-first century, research into the history of urban planning in China has been a common area of focus in planning academia. As the number of interested parties and scholars engaged in the study of planning history has continued to grow, a substantial body of academic publications has been accumulated
PLANNING PERSPECTIVES
ROUTLEDGE
Routledge
Taylor & Francis Group
CONTACT Baihao Li libaihaowh@sina.com

aee aee eae ee eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eae eee
uONCS SHdI

and an academic community has become established. After three preparatory meetings between 2009 and 2011, the Academic Committee of Planning History and Theory<sup>2</sup> was formally established in 2012.<sup>3</sup> The ACPHT is a professional academic organization affiliated with the Urban Planning Society of China, which unites the majority of researchers in the field, conducts research into the history, practice, and theory of urban planning and academic exchanges, and promotes the development of urban and rural planning in China. In 2011, urban and rural planning became an independent first-level discipline, rather than just a secondary discipline of architecture. Planning history as a secondary subject in urban and rural planning is an integral part of urban and rural planning. It also serves as a professional history and offers basic information for all research in the discipline of urban and rural planning. The promotion of the status of the discipline and the establishment of the academic community greatly contributed to the development of planning history research, which has produced fruitful results in the last decade. This paper takes the opportunity to review, reflect upon, and summarize past achievements in order to promote the continuous innovation of planning history and theory.
Data and methods
Data

This study compiled master theses, doctoral dissertations, journal papers<sup>4</sup>, and conference papers on planning history written in Chinese and published in China by Chinese and foreign scholars from 2011 to 2020. The terms 'planning history' and 'urban planning history' were used in searches, while 'title', 'keywords', and 'full text' were used as the search fields in each of the corresponding databases. The database selected for theses/dissertations was the China National Knowledge Infrastructure Theses and Dissertations Database, supplemented by the theses/dissertations database of the eight leading schools<sup>5</sup> in the field of architecture. Journal articles were searched in seven major academic journals<sup>6</sup> on urban planning. The conference papers were retrieved from the conference proceedings of the Annual National Planning Conference<sup>7</sup> (urban planning history and theory section) and the ACPHT Conference.<sup>8</sup> Multiple search criteria were used to ensure data integrity. A total of 1,057 articles were selected, including 198 theses/dissertations, 465 journal papers, and 394 conference papers. Theses/dissertations include the most advanced and cutting-edge research results. Journal papers reflect the latest research achievements in the academic field. Conference papers mirror the academic focus and latest trends. Thus, the selected articles balanced breadth, depth, and topicality, and they offered a comprehensive representation of the last decade of research into the history of urban planning in China.
Methods

This study analysed the hotspots and evolution of China's urban planning history research between 2011 and 2020 by combining quantitative and qualitative methods. In the quantitative analysis, basic statistics about the 1,057 records were obtained to gain a direct understanding of annual publishing trends and authors with high publishing volumes, before CiteSpace was used to conduct bibliometric analysis of the data. Keyword co-occurrences, bursts, and clustering graphs were generated using a software algorithm to intuitively understand the research hotspots. Based on the quantitative analysis and supported by the literature, this paper qualitatively concludes and summarizes the research contents and the evolution of Chinese urban planning history over the past decade.
IPHS SECTION
Statistics, hotspots, and clustering
Basic statistics

As can be seen from the line chart (Figure 1), the annual total number fluctuated widely over the decade, starting at 85 in 2011, rising to 121 in 2013, reaching a low point in 2014 and 2015, and returning to high levels from 2016 to 2018, with the highest amount of 132 occurring in 2018, before dropping and reaching the lowest level in 2020. The variation trend for the journal papers is the same as that of the total number. The annual number of conference papers presented a fluctuating upward trend between 2011 and 2019. In 2020, the Annual National Planning Conference was not held, while the ACPHT Conference was held online due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Consequently, the number of conference papers decreased to 26. The annual number of dissertations was always around 20 during the decade, except in 2013.

After excluding the documents without abstracts and keywords, 946 out of a total of 1,057 records were imported into CiteSpace. By taking the authors as a node, a co-author map was drawn, containing 898 nodes and 640 edges (Figure 2). Baihao Li had the highest number of publications and highest centrality, followed by Hao Li, Yishi Liu, Kang Cao, and Tinghai Wu. Other authors who published numerous articles are listed in Table 1.
Research hotspots

As a summary and refinement of article content by authors, keywords can reflect the core idea and content of literature. Their inclusion in many papers from the same profession can also offer significant insights, for example, into the status quo, hotspots, development context, and trends in the subjects of research. Therefore, this study analysed research hotspots and their trends through keyword co-occurrence and clustering.

By taking 'keywords' as a node and setting up the time slice to one year, a keyword co-occurrence graph was generated, with 179 nodes and 285 edges (Figure 3). 'Evolution', 'early-modern time', 'urban morphology', 'urbanization', and 'urban form' constitute portraits of research hot-spots, in addition to broad keywords, such as 'urban planning', 'urban planning history', and
Figure 1. Total number of annual research outputs and number of annual research outputs by category.

Research clustering
Based on the keyword co-occurrence network, clustering refines and summarizes research topics and visually displays the main research fields, with the principle of generating knowledge clustering

through a clustering algorithm and extracting tag keywords through the algorithm to represent the corresponding research frontier. The log-likelihood ratio (LLR) clustering technique was used, as it is the most reliable labelling technique for generating high-quality clusters with minimum overlapping. Cluster labels were obtained from a pool of keywords, and clusters were labelled in ascending order based on cluster size.

The Q and S values of the clustering were 0.800 and 0.938 (> 0.5 and 0.3), respectively, indicating high clustering reliability. The top 10 labels were: (1) human settlement environment, (2) urban planning, (3) evolution, (4) planning history, (5) public space, (6) urban morphology, (7) China, (8) Beijing, (9) spatial evolution, and (10) spatial structure (Figure 4). The keywords contained in the cluster are listed in Table 3.

Review and analysis of research content

The content in this research domain cannot be fully understood using only cluster labels. Supplemented by reading support and referring to the classification of planning history studies by domestic and foreign scholars, the research content of Chinese urban planning history in the past decade can be summarized into the following five aspects.
IPHS SECTION
Research into planning practice

Research into the history of domestic planning practice is the most productive category, which can be divided into ancient (before 1840), early-modern (1840-1949), and modern (1949-present) planning practice research, according to the date range.
Ancient planning practice

Ancient planning practice research can be summarized as follows: (1) research into the planning and construction of ancient capital cities; (2) research into the planning and construction of non-capital cities; (3) research into defence systems and military settlements; (4) research into the construction of human settlements; (5) research into urban patterns; (6) the historical evolution of ancient city forms; (7) review of Western studies on Chinese urban form; (8) urban planning techniques in ancient China.
Early-modern planning practice

Among the research into early-modern (1840-1949) planning practice, studies on case cities have always been a very important aspect, consisting of historical staging and a summary of characteristics based on the identification of historical sources and their interpretation. The studied cities can be divided into the following categories: (1) colonies, concessions, settlements, and railway-affiliated cities; (2) treaty ports; (3) self-opening commercial ports; (4) inland cities.

Meanwhile, a lot of research into planning practice has been conducted from a national or regional perspective, such as Research into the Development of Shanxi Early-modern Urban Planning. Moreover, studies have been carried out on the planning practices of municipal parks and university campuses, which are new types of urban spaces, such as the campus planning of Associated Christian Colleges hosted by Walter Gropius in Shanghai, the Xiamen University Plan of Henry K. Murphy, Tsinghua University, Tianjin University, Jimei University, and Taiwan University, among others.
Modern planning practice

First, a large number of planning practice reviews and experience summary types of research were carried out by utilizing the opportunities presented by the 40th anniversary of reform and opening up (2018)
and the 70th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China (PRC, 2019).

The history of China's modern urban planning began with the founding of the PRC in 1949, when the Soviet model of urban planning was introduced into China through top-down recommendations.[18] The paradigm of planning has undergone a transformation from the European and American model to the Soviet model. In 1960, the slogan 'not undertaking urban planning for three years'[19] signalled the beginning of nearly 20 years of stagnation in the national planning business. Drawing considerable attention in the research into the history of modern urban planning, this period covered the formation of modern urban planning in China under the influence of the Soviet model, the construction of the planning system, the assistance of Soviet experts for China's planning cause, and specific planning practices including eight key urban plans[20], and 156 projects.[21] Chinese cities have been in a phase of rapid urbanization since the reform and opening up in 1978, along with institutional reforms and rapid economic development. An increasing number of scholars have begun to focus on this period of research containing two main types: the
PLANNING PERSPECTIVES
planning practices of emerging cities, such as Shenzhen and Pudong in Shanghai, and the planning transformations of existing ancient cities, such as Guangzhou, Nanjing, and Xi'an.
Research into planning system construction
Research into institutional history investigated two thematic: urban planning systems and the law.

The research content of the urban planning system has the following three aspects according to different research time periods. First, researchers identified and combed through ancient texts to study a particular period
or a specific planning system in ancient China (before 1840), such as the system of two capitals. The second is the construction of an urban planning system in the Republic of China
(1911-1949) and research into the planning system of case cities.

The third part concerns China's modern urban planning system which demonstrates two particular characteristics. First, it reviewed the construction of China's modern urban planning system from 1949 to 1978, legal, compilation, and management systems, as well as other subsystems of China's modern urban planning, such as changes in the urban planning system since
, the innovation, diffusion, and transformation of the planning committee system since the reform and opening up and the planning institute system and the development of urban planning.
Second, it studied the construction and development of modern planning systems in other countries, including the United Kingdom
, France
, Japan, and Korea
, with a view to drawing lessons for current planning management and practice.

Comparatively few studies have been carried out on planning law. A notable example comprises Jinhong Niu's Analysis on the Culture of Modern Chinese City Planning Law.[30] Considering the evolution of urban planning legal thought and institutions in three important cities, including Beijing, Nanjing, and Shanghai, as a basic clue, the study explored key issues, such as important institutional organization, management style, planning legal thought, and important planning legal documents emerging at each stage of urban planning administration. It also summarized the historical process and basic development features and laws of localized urban planning legal thought in modern China, and summed up the historical process of localization development in China's early-modern urban planning law and basic characteristics and regulations.
Research into planning thought and theory

A discipline becomes independent because of its core theory. After urban and rural planning became a principal academic discipline in China, the establishment and improvement of planning theory became an urgent task.[31] At present, research into Chinese planning thought and theory has been mainly carried out from existing planning thought and theory.

The research into planning thought carried out in the past decade can be categorized as follows: (1) research into modern urban planning thought; (2) planning thought in domestic planning practice; (3) China's ancient planning thought; (4) review of the evolution of modern Chinese planning thought over the past seven decades. The study of modern planning thought expounded the formation backgrounds, evolution, dissemination, and practices of the Garden City<sup>32</sup>, Linear City Idea<sup>33</sup>, Green Wedge Idea<sup>34</sup>, and hexagonal planning theory.<sup>35</sup> The planning ideas in practical cases include the campus planning of Tsinghua University, the planning of Five Great Avenues in Tianjin, and the Puppet Manchukuo 'New Capital (Xinjing)', Guangzhou, Qingdao, Chongqing, Lanzhou, and so on.
IPHS SECTION

Planning theory research can be classified into two parts. The first is a review of Western urban planning theories in the past century.[36] The second involves combing through and thinking about the progress of China's planning theory since 1978 and the course of internationalization.[37]
Research into planning figures

Over the past decade a considerable number of studies on planning figures have been carried out. These have identified the influence of figures on the construction of case city planning and even the contribution to the construction or transformation of China's urban planning system by combing through the biographies of planning figures, educational experiences, planning practices and ideas, and writing. Currently, most of the research results are focused on early-modern planning figures, such as Tiangu Cheng (1889-1974)
, Xiujia Dong (1891-?)
, Harris Wen (Ha Xiongwen, 1907-1981)
, Zukang Zhao (1900-1995)
, Honglie Shen (1882-1969)
, and Charles Chen

(Chen Zhanxiang, 1916-2001). Charles Chen studied in the Department of Urban Design at the University of Liverpool under the guidance of Sir Patrick Abercrombie and participated in the Greater London Plan). In addition, the article A Study on the Typology of Modern Chinese Urban Planning Figures Based on Educational Background

also proposed a paradigm for the classification of planning figures, arguing that modern urban planning figures can be divided into planning and architecture, engineering, law and economics, and other categories. A few achievements were made by relatively late studies on the history of modern urban planning figures
, including Ganzhi Zhou (1930-2014) and Soviet experts, such as A.S. Mukhin (1900-1982).

The study of planning figures provided a clearer understanding of the development and transformation of Chinese urban planning in modern times. It is also of great significance to further enrich and improve the research system of urban planning history in China.
Research into the development of the discipline of Chinese planning

A considerable amount of research has been conducted on the history of China's urban planning discipline. Representative research results include A Study on the History of Urban Planning Education in Early-modern China by Wanli Zhang and a series of research into the development of the major urban planning of Tongji University.[48] The origins and progress of the planning discipline were elucidated by identifying historical sources and interpreting them. The discipline of urban planning in China emerged in the 1920s from three disciplines: civil engineering, architecture, and municipal administration.[49] In 1952, the first systematic urban planning major was established. In 2011, urban planning was no longer a second-level discipline under architecture, but had developed into a first-level discipline. Apart from clarifying the context of development, the study summarized the characteristics of discipline development.
Conclusion

A comprehensive analysis of quantitative statistics and the knowledge mapping of literature and important research content reveals the following characteristics of research into the history of Chinese urban planning in the last decade.
Despite fluctuations in the number of articles published in the last decade, a general upward trend can be seen in scholarly interest in the field of planning history. Due to the establishment
PLANNING PERSPECTIVES

of the academic community, the ACPHT, more scholars have clarified their research directions and attached the keyword 'urban planning history' to their articles, thus forming a keyword co-occurrence node about 'urban planning history', with high centrality on the picture. In the meantime, the fruitful research results of the 'History of Early-modern Urban Planning in China' can be seen. In the last decade, research has focused on the history of modern planning, as well as more diverse objects and content. In terms of temporal scope, the focus on the history of planning in the Republic of China period is complemented by a significant increase in attention to the history of post-1949 and ancient planning. The geographical scope of the study extends from a focus on the built-up areas to the entire municipal area including natural elements; the perspective extends from urban to regional, and the distribution of cases extends from the eastern coast to the vast and central inland areas of China. Research case types have become increasingly broad. For example, ancient planning studies have focused not only on capital cities, but also on cities in general, and modern studies have not only focused on cities at ports of commerce, but also on cities at self-opening ports of commerce and non-ports of commerce. The research contents delve into the exploration of motivations and mechanisms, planning ideology, methodology, practice subjects, and preparation process based on a staged review of the historical process of practice and a summary of its characteristics. In the past ten years, planning history research in China has shown a process from partial to holistic and fragmented to systematic in general terms and has formed a complete planning history research system.
